Nr5RfGApgVWLtF7r8M1GJg.text: I was so excited to see Ippudo opening in London as I loved the place when I first tried it in Hong Kong. But being well known with many people around the world it is no surprise there is a queue. I waited for 1 1/2 hours for a table of four but happy to as we could go away for a drink and wait for them to text us when a table was ready.Ippudo currently has to be my favourite ramen restaurant in London as the flavour of the broth is the best. But only downside is the ramen does not come standard with an egg and you have to order it as an add-on. An interested add on to the ramen is the curry ball which is a small curry paste ball served separately.  Add it to your ramen and it instantly become a tasty curry broth ramen. You can order one portion and share between two or three people as a little bit is enough to infuse a curry broth,  unless you prefer a strong curry broth.As well as ramen there are a range of appetiser to order including gyzoa and even Ippudo version of fish and chips. Then to complete a ramen meal you can finish with a range of Ippudo desserts. Yum!!!

o9ddK4tJNY09liDxnpoJog.text: I love ramen, but I am REALLY picky with it, specially being vegetarian, so Ippudo was a really nice surprise.I ordered the vegetarian ramen and the broth was really tasty, the size big enough to make you feel satisfied and the flavour...amazing. The service was amazing too, and they make you feel welcome.I will definitely come back to Ippudo, I have been talking about this place to everyone I know...!

ao3epAgDv3GU0MFlCI6lug.text: I came here on a Saturday night before 6pm, it's best to get there before the dinner rush. I ordered the ippudo akamaru modern, with extra sides. What is ramen without a proper egg? I am a fan or tonkatsu ramen, and the broth here does the job. Order a bottle of sake to share with a friend and you are good.

B8m5A0JJhltYG3VgLS0Yxg.text: I haven't been to so many ramen places in London yet, but I guess it is fairly good one. We ordered Shiromaru, Akamaru with seasoned boiled egges, and Yamitsuki goma kyuri. The total price was 35 pounds, which I thought was really expensive for ramen.... but it might be a normal price for London. The tonkotsu broth was good, the eggs were seasoned nicely, Kyuri's sauce was okay but might need some more strong taste. There were many staffs enough to take care of the customers and they were all nice and lively just as I see in ramen places in Japan. The place is cleaner than Japanese ones, which is good. I also recognized some Japanese staffs.The only problem is that it is not really a cheap eat here in London.

BiI4ub51EVNcWO6QtWp4IA.text: The pork ramen and gyozas are extremely tasty. My wife and I really enjoyed the food at this place. Fairly expensive, but the noodle refills are very reasonably priced, so I recommend you get some. Be aware that you will experience (White, British) waiters shouting barely comprehensible Japanese at customers with little enthusiasm, and communal seating (although it's still fairly spacious). If you can get over that, this place serves some really good ramen.

ZWv57VUBc6Es1zmximf6Lw.text: Love their daily special and their amazing free bun promotions! Plus, they have an impressive selection of sakes and gyozas. I'm sold.

m8tjspVVPXyld-QxCOSUtA.text: Ramen is ok. Everything else is overpriced for the small portion that you get. We had a good time when we went there soon after the opening, but now the service was really bad. The dishes were not corresponding to their description and many order were taken simply wrong (not just ours, the people at tables around us had similar issues).For the poshness that they want to show we were mistreated (even for the simple thing, you don't deserve a small plate if you share gyoza...)Not going back. There are better options for excellent ramen in London

EmDkNxVO54j3k3tpj9PZOw.text: Nope. Had high expectation but like another Yelper had mentioned, there is this aura of overbearing pretentiousness that isn't justified by good ramen. It's the same company, but not the same ramen and vibe. The small mom-and-pop ramen shop across the street gets more customers than this giant. Won't be coming back.

FY_qBeJhTSbUcV6zuN-fUg.text: after a few days in London, i was craving some good asian food and i had previously dined at Ippudo in NYC so i knew i could rely on the Ippudo name for a hearty bowl of ramen haha...and i was not let down! i think this is a fairly new location and it's located right near the Google London building. me and justin b. showed up right at opening expecting a long line, but to our surprise, there was no one waiting and we were seated right away. the place looks sleek and modern and we were seated on the main level but it looks like there is more space on the 2nd floor too. i ordered an Ippudo favorite, the Akamaru Modern with a boiled egg (extra 1.50) since i feel it has more flavor to it than their classic bowl. at 11 pounds, its not a cheap bowl of ramen...but its a good bowl of ramen haha. it was hearty and flavorful and it hit the spot on a cold London evening.

089Ng6E45N8FuJ_zMCPj1w.text: Ippudo. Where I go when I want a quick, filling and adequate bowl of ramen. This place is like the Nando's of ramen. It's not going to blow your mind, but it will be good enough that you're not walking away disappointed like you would from so many other ramen shops in London. This is probably because it's a Japanese chain. They know how to make their ramen and this bowl is pretty comparable to the one I had in NYC from the same chain. Unfortunately, the pork buns are not nearly as good. I think they are doing something different here (more mayo in the sauce perhaps?), but I guess you have to get one if you've never had one...they are good, just not AS good. Solid 7/10 ramen, but pricey and very limited on their other items.

yoGJtLUofL2kxSgEFlE2OQ.text: Delicious ramen and lovely starters too.My friends and I arrived and they had no table for us, but the bar is a big enough that it didn't feel like an imposition to sit there for the 15 minutes it took for a table to clear for us. We were sat in a corner and the food was really good! We shared the chicken buns and vegetable buns and the fish & chips as starters, then each got a ramen. Mine was the Aka Vegetarian with the Boiled Egg. I can honetsly say that the broth had a rich flavour and the umami ball added complexity to the dish that is often quite boring.I will definitely be visiting again.

LWVLa8TVWNUlzDokNn-LzQ.text: Decent ramen but nothing close to Kanada Ya across the street in terms of taste/quality/authenticity. Service was very friendly but a bit confusing/ overwhelming. Was pressured into drinking so much water I feel waterboarded. This has made me bloated and antisocial. Chicken Hirata Buns tasted identical to McChicken burgers. Sesame panacotta tastes like i just dipped my tongue in a nightclub ashtray and have left a foul taste in my mouth contrary to the purpose and institution of dessert. Too much noise and unecessary screaming directed to noone in particular in japanese by clearly non-japanese people. What are you saying? All together alright experience but do not think I will be back soon.

3iZIZ11n9naRxT8QJL3cwg.text: When I think of a ramen hangout I always look back to my trip to Ramen Alley in Sapporo, Japan and how small and intimate they are. However when you turn up at Ippudo it feels like it's another commercial franchise restaurant. Saying that the staff were still extremely polite. I started with a few Hirata Buns, the filings were tasty, slightly lacking on size and you can get better elsewhere. I also really like spice so went for the Karaka Spicy Men ramen. Personally I thought it was over spiced and it did start to over power the very flavoursome broth after a few mouthfuls. They also catch you out by providing a basic ramen and then you have to add toppings to complete it, making it overpriced for what you get. At least throw an egg in. If you are a traditionalist there are definitely better Ramen restaurants in London, but it is still OK to check out if you are passing by and need some quick comfort food. (Visit - 26/02/2015 Dinner)

KmN7TtDUNBMbbkU9b0HnMQ.text: It saves my stomach from disgusting British food in London. What more can I say? The service is great. The place is clean. There's no wait. Tasted a bit lighter (which I prefer)  than the one I tried in Taiwan.

CjyLb23DRKQT7xo4Q_7LYQ.text: Ramen good but nothing special. Very disorganised service.  Poor staff was friendly but absolutely frantic!  Restroom broken.  They were out of eggs but it's part of their signature ramen dish.  Just okay.

DgoF48vCDle8_SOZvRTy1Q.text: When I look at the menu I was surprised by the wide range of dishes they have as I've been to Kanada-Ya, right opposite Ippudo, previously and their menu was so small. Ippudo even had fish & chips and steak, with a twist though. I ordered the £10 student meal which was so good as it included a bowl of ramen, a portion of gyoza and a drink. Usually the ramen is already over £10 on its own. I shared this with my friend and we ordered some hirata buns and desserts to share. The broth was rich which was tasty but different to Ippudo, the buns were fluffy and the gyoza had golden crispy skin on the outside filled with juicy, meaty filling.The staff was friendly and helpful and all the staff would always greet you when you arrive and when you leave by shouting out Japanese words such as 'welcome' and 'thank you'. Think this is a Japanese restaurant cultural thing but can be awkward as I assume most people here wouldn't know what to say or even what the words mean. But overall it's a great ramen bar in London. The broth taste richer and better than Shoryu and has a wider menu than Kanada-Ya. I would definitely go back!

photos.caption: Photo of Ippudo London - London, United Kingdom. Matcha gelato with a layer of mascarpone cheese on top. Sprinkled with crushed pistachio and matcha powder on the side.
Photo of Ippudo London - London, United Kingdom. Black sesame panna cotta served with a scoop of mango sorbet and a light dusting of kinako powder. Not too sweet, perfect!
Photo of Ippudo London - London, United Kingdom. Soft white fluffy hirata buns stuffed with fried aubergine and pork belly cooked in sweet sauce, lettuce and Mayo.

W1-YDUhHzKvA2tYqjBKFlQ.text: Terrible for vegetarians - only limited items and they're cooked in the same oil as non-vegetarian items. Have enjoyed their food in New York where this isn't the case so very disappointed that they don't have the same standards in London.

o1IRV654UqTcNq1kHDlDDg.text: I've been waiting for a reunion with my favorite ramen hotspot in New York since last year, when I found out Ippudo was opening up a location in London.  There has not been a dearth of ramen slurping since I've arrived in London, however, with ramen masters sprouting up all over the city like rabid mushrooms. Ippudo is up against serious contenders.The ambiance was just as I remembered it in New York, slightly brooding and sexy, if you could call a ramen house sexy.  I arrived on a Friday night at 6 pm ready to get my noodle game on and was surprised the wait was only about 20 minutes for a table of two.Once seated, I ordered my usual, the Hirata Buns for 7 quid and Akamaru Modern for 11 quid. I always thought the Ippudo's prices in New York were hard to swallow (or slurp) but I guess they're a bargain compared to their prices in London.  I've never been impressed by the Hirata Buns, and I still uphold that opinion. They're okay, and very minimalist compared to other buns I've had.The NOODLES. One thing Ippudo has always excelled at is the noodles. No one can do springy and sleek when it comes to noodles like Ippudo. The bowl was kept simple, with fair portions of pork belly chashu, bean sprouts, mushrooms, and spring onions. The broth was a bit too salty, and this is where I think Bone Daddies is slightly stronger- keeping the broth's flavor without compromising saltiness.This is the only ramen place in London I've finished everything. The portions are just right and satisfied the craving without making me feel like pork fat was seeping out of my pores. Definitely coming back, but boycotting the Hirata Buns.

MU5hmaIz9qbcDUyY8ha_cg.text: We came here on a chilly Sunday after visiting the Britsh Museum which is nearby. It looks a bit hipster. There is reasonably loud 80s music playing and literally everyone greets you with an 'irrashaimase' as you walk from door to table.We perused the menus and they had a supplementary smaller menu with specials. I went for their signature ramen, the Shiromara Hikata Classic. This is a tonkotsu pork broth with a piece of pork loin. The broth was fine, but had a subtle greasy aftertaste. I wanted to eat something else to balance it out. My wife had one of the special spicy ramens. The noodles were a bit overdone for her, but she does prefer them to be a bit under. The broth was not as spicy as she was expecting, but it was nonetheless good.The people are friendly and it feels like they have 'learnt the script' well. The ramen came out quickly after we had ordered and this was appreciated on a cold day.

OCHC0OJl9UEEEvybRVXieA.text: Ramen on the posh you say?  Well, that's novel.  What really impressed me about ippudo is the consistency.  I had ippudo after going to the Instant noodle museum in Ikeda in Japan a couple months ago (it was a noodlelicious morning) and I was amazed to find that as much as I could remember, the two bowls of noodles tasted the same.  Except one was a regular looking ramen joint (ok, comparatively expensive ramen joint for Japan) and we got a giant plate of fried rice for like an extra pound and the other is an upscale Japanese restaurant in the middle of London.  Wowza.  Loving that.The Akamaru differs from the regular in that it has a blob of red umami-filled miso-y "secret recipe" paste and garlic oil.  So, if it's your first time, just order that and try the soup before you swirl it around and you've pretty much tried both types.  I prefer the red to white, but that's personal taste.  The noodles were pretty bog standard, pork excellent and I am a little sad it didn't come with an egg- they need to do a "special" version with egg and 2 slice of char sui here.  I'm sure that would sell like wildfire!We split the gyoza (ok, I will keep my beef with gyoza only fried on one side to myself) and some gorgeous pickles.  Beer wise, I'd highly recommend their Belgium brewed Japanese beer- it's a dark beer and it's exactly how you'd imagine a "Japanese-fied" Belgium dark beer would taste like- slightly exaggerated, oh so slightly too perfect and therefore possibly a tiny bit fake? but oh my god so good (as with all Japanese manufactured western food items and fruits).Like Josy, I felt that the shouting was an overkill.  It's just that my experience in Japan (and the rest of Asia as far as I've tried), people say Irrashaimase with their indoor voices.  It could be a loudish indoor voice, but definitely not some bloody oh-god-one-direction-is-coming-on-stage-let's-storm-the-stage scream.  The restaurant is in a glass structure for christ sake.  Glass doesn't really absorb sound that well so it was super noisy.  Call me old and old fashion, but when indoors, keep your indoor voice on.  Ok?Overall, fabulous ramen, I'd come back here any time but probably with some ear plugs next time.

3h360xk3Wo0hrhJRW3pKmg.text: I knew about Ippudo because of my last year trip to Japan; and I still cannot forget the ramen we tried there: OUTSTANDING! In fact, we when twice to Ippudo during our stay in Kyoto and we also went to Ippudo some days later in Tokyo. We also tried Ippudo at NY East Village. The menu in the London restaurant is similar to the Japanese one. And the food is also excellent! I found the noodles just slightly worse in comparison to the previous times. However, there were a couple of differences in comparison to the Japan and NY restaurants that I didn't like at all. First, the restaurant does not have the cozy ambiance I found in Japan and NY. In fact, the restaurant looks like a modern restaurant difficult to identify with the traditional japanese dishes. Second, the service was kind of bad. The waiters were anxious to retire our bowls and they seemed to be depress. Just the opposite I found in Japan and NY, where the waiters were enthusiastic and speaking a much more credible japanese!Overall, I gave 4 points just because I am always willing to reward nice ramen (which unfortunately is still difficult to find).I am sure that I'll be back to NY's and Japan's Ippudo restaurants... but it seems unlikely I'll be back to Ippudo London in my next trip to the UK.

B_k5fiOeFyNdaotXJnYxGQ.text: A place to go if you're hungry for a ramen. It's huge! I went with 5 other friends and none of us finished. We are all students, so we got the promotion (gyoza + traditional ramen + a drink of your choice for £10). This was pretty good; however, I don't think it would be worth the original price (out of the promotion).Ambience is not the best. Staff seem very serious about the tradition, but the music (a mix of Rihanna and Calvin Harris) didn't quite match the place.

8qhctDXN3axT4ingrlUfqw.text: If standing in a queue for mediocre, no-frills ramen served against the backdrop of incongruous, loud music with staff who whiz past without glancing your way is your thing, then Ippudo is for you. I've never been to the other, global Ippudo locations, but my visit to the new London location was disappointing. Limp, flavorless noodles served with minimal ingredients for £10 ... would much rather queue for Kanada-Ya's superior ramen directly across the road. It seemed to be overstaffed during our visit, and yet, several plaintive "Excuse me?" for water, bill, and for someone to take our order went ignored. I'm spoilt for choice when it comes to ramen in London, with Tonkotsu East, Shoryu, and Kanada-Ya all virtually on my home/work doorsteps ... so I won't be returning to Ipuudo any time soon.

F6nXjmotLDQERo_0ZWohKQ.text: As a person from California and Bay Area - I've had numerous opportunity to try Japanese ramen. With the announcement of Ippudo, opening in London I was ecstatic and the ramen reassured my belief. Was it life shattering ramen - not really, but still the best ramen in London.

photos.caption: Photo of Ippudo London - London, United Kingdom

rqle86VsinwTxu578iWjtg.text: Unbelievable terrible experience! It's so ridiculous that they refused to take orders from one of my friends who arrived late. And even worse, they tried to make my friend sit at a separate table away from us, and only by doing that can they take orders from her. Can you imagine a normal business do this? They insist "it's store policy" but sorry policy for what? I've been to ippudo Tokyo and Shanghai, no one did that! Or maybe special policy for London? Sorry other London restaurants are never that rude to customers!

HfQdiUi4zr2hr2YOHN7zZQ.text: A ramen japanese concept, which I wish I would have read before attending. Reasonable prices for inner city London although obviously felt a little bit like a franchise on the way in. Friendly and kinda personal but not really. Although service is better here than most places. Anyhow unfortunately I didn't order the ramen, which was rather tasty. The gyuzo was good and the edimame was the norm. I had a black cod which was nice but far from the best portion I have ever had, although reasonably tasty if I was on a diet. The sapporo beer was excellent, shame I couldn't have a few more. Maybe a place to come again, although there r so many Japanese restaurants to try.

photos.caption: Photo of Ippudo London - London, United Kingdom. Eat and be happy in a komono
Photo of Ippudo London - London, United Kingdom. Great beer
Photo of Ippudo London - London, United Kingdom. The napkin

jfO-Fff3CuqAmV_1mhB74A.text: I'm sorry but this is not a legit ramen place. The place is extremely fake as in a "wanna be" because employees there spoke crappy Japanese phrases (almost to the point it should be considered as mockery). If you're going to speak it, learn how to speak it correctly! There is nothing more annoying than having 10 staff members shouting the same thing over and over again when entering and exiting the eatery. In terms of the food, I think that eatery was just half arsing everything - especially being very stingy on the chashu. This is another type of chain eatery that is out there to rip off people that don't know any better. I would avoid the place at all cost. I know ramen places are scarce in London but please don't go in there out of desperation. It is not anything like what you'd get in an authentic ramen place in Japan, San Francisco, Los Angeles or New York.I would never go back there for sure. I hope more ramen places will open in London where people wouldn't find ramen to be such rare or exotic food but instead evolve into just a normal food option (sit, eat and out).

2hC5fRrBDy9oAok2JJPbVw.text: I've had Ippudo in NYC and Sydney- both were very impressive. So I was quite excited when Ippudo London opened. For consistency comparison I ordered the Akamaru ramen (red bowl; pork belly with miso paste). The broth was light and flavoursome and the noodles were soft... BUT only one piece of pork belly for a £11 bowl noodle? I was very disappointed with the portion size especially since I've fond memories from the other restaurants. Ramen is a "thing" in London at the moment- there are many places I'd go back to before coming back to Ippudo in London.

RytHXCWd2KpZfy6u4pqigw.text: the broth is good.Both the white bowl and the red bowl.Soup has a shrimp roe taste to it in addition to the pork bone taste.1 slide of pork only per bowl!However,unlike Kanada-ya, you cannot choose how dente you want the ramen.Eel on rice is also authentic.Be prepared to queue up.4 star for London.3 star compared to Japan.unlike Kanada-ya across the road ,Ippudo charges 12.5% service charge

6dEWfWC_O5BiaJISfGVd_w.text: Very nice very solid bowl of ramen. A tad pricy for the rest of the menu but can't say I didn't enjoy the food nontheless!

photos.caption: Photo of Ippudo London - London, United Kingdom. This was fantastic.
Photo of Ippudo London - London, United Kingdom. yum. don't forget to add extra egg
Photo of Ippudo London - London, United Kingdom. nice deco

uumEJOwWjR2kXOmzevZjXA.text: Will and Joey from the NYC branches have done a wonderful job of recreating the service and atmosphere of the branches in the US at the new London location. The ramen is almost identical in taste once you add a little spice to the dish and the signature chicken buns are deliciously addictive.I'm so glad that Ippudo has made the move to the UK, and now takes the crown from Bone Daddies as the best ramen in town!

6uiKzq5IEhwm4XyTEf-2EA.text: "I can't believe I'm queuing up for ramen" says the guy in front of me in the queue to enter Ippudo. and I think to myself, "so true, why am I queuing up for ramen?" In truth, it was my friend Pen L. who successfully talked me into it. Well after queueing for around 15mins (even if timed your arrival directly on opening time), expect to be greeted with a Japanese welcome into the restaurant by every single member of staff you pass (frankly I feel sorry for the staff who have to keep chanting this greeting all night long), then you will be seated and served by people from all walks of life. It would seem that for most of the staff, English is not their first language, which is fine until you find yourself slowly repeating your question in order to elicit an answer. Nevertheless, the food was nicely presented, the noodles sufficiently succulent to be memorable and the variety available from the menu was decent. The portions are quite small but this works out well if you want to try out out a full 3 courses. The food does take quite some time to arrive but you can tell that attention has been dedicated to its preparation. Ippudo has a little more style over substance but all in all, a worthwhile visit and an original experience.

oX7xDBKAq5xjdUnsJBSKdg.text: Having tried the NYC and Sydney versions I was happy to hear that a branch was opening in London!!!Comparatively it sits comfortably in the middle of the three, not quite as good as NYC but streets ahead of Sydney (which was awful) The venue is pretty funky and welcoming, there is a bar where you can wait and have a drink and the rest of the restaurant is was surprisingly bigger than I first thought, but they pack the tables in so your pretty close to other diners.The food was good!! We had the pork bun and gyoza, the bun was really good but gyoza didn't really impress me. We had two different Ramens both very tasty, but they don't come with an Egg unless ordered as an extra, I was left a little miffed having ordered it but it then turning up without it.... I couldn't be bothered to wait so went without. The service was very good the waiter knew the menu and made good recommendations. I'm still to try the place opposite that has some glowing reviews but I would certainly be coming back.

N0CjdDM1hqFajaf_aibdRA.text: To be honest the poor service overshadowed the Ramen on my visit. Which is a shame, because the others have given the ramen here such wonderful reviews. All of the staff we interacted with, including the main host, were curt and rude. The highlight was when the waiter repeatedly insisted the glass of red wine he served me was a Sauvignon Blanc. It felt too chainy and the whole izakaya vibe just wasn't working.

zWvG7xzdnm68cGtHHnImWg.text: Un-amazing ramen place.  Has a good beer called 'Owa' Japanese beer made in Belgium.  Some good buns, plate of three for £10 is a good starter.  Ramen only average and honestly, though it's professional enough, and cannot complain about the service, prices are on the high side and I am not sure I'd be racing back.  Lacks soul, I suppose.  It is after all a chain and it's a bog-standard kind of deal, and not somewhere you'd get too wild about.

C5B7h6EAS72piPJwnYIqYg.text: Do yourself a favor and go to Tonkotsu instead!!! It's unfortunate I can't give this place 0 stars. I am a celiac and I am super flexible when it comes to eating. I completely understand not having gluten free noodles. I asked to replace the noodles in my ramen with vegetables, The server said yes. My food came and it was broth by itself. Next delivered was every ingredient promised to be in the ramen in its own individual bowl. I found this to be strange but didn't over think it. Finally The bill came and I was charged for every ingredient in the ramen separately on top of the standard ramen price. So for £12 you get broth. They even charge you for sriracha.

BKumY53-9drXEA9T7h4KLg.text: This was a solid bowl of ramen. I've never had ramen in London on account of better more classic things to eat but I have had ramen from Ippudo's original locations in Tokyo as well as other gold standards like Ichiran. All in this ramen was pretty excellent and as advertised. The only thing that took this place from 5 to 4 was the service and the ambiance. The service was kind of slow- they told us to pick a bunch of combo menu items as that was technically cheaper than the a la carte items we ordered but then some of them didn't show up and we had to ask for them. The other issue on ambiance was that tables near the front and the kitchen started to smell sewer and when that happened staff would wash a bin worth of soap water down the floor drains in the kitchen which fixed the sewer gas issue but made the area smell like chemicals. Until this is figured out try to sit in the back. Despite this the food itself was great.

KHDAgIIhzWTQofVswnZRCQ.text: In my PRD (pre ramen days), Cocoro was virtually the only place in London which served proper tonkotsu ramen. Then, I headed to New York on holiday and came across IppudoI still remember that epiphany with my first slurp of the creamy, salty, fatty broth and I was in love. My initial sadness on returning to ramen-less London has been tempered over the last few years by the wave of specialist ramen restaurants opening across the capital over the last 2 years. While London still can't match the breadth of ramen restaurants compared to places like the Bay Area, I think the best of London (Bone Daddies in my opinion) is pretty good these daysHowever, I did get a pang of nostalgic excitement when I heard that Ippudo were opening in London. I hurried down there last Sunday to see if they had brought their A game to LondonThere was a small queue at 7pm but the 30 minute estimated wait time I was give turned out to only be 5 minutes. I like the Japanese greetings shouted by the staff as you enter the restaurant even if it did seriously irk one of London's more popular bloggersI went for the Akamaru Modern, where the basic tonkotsu is augmented by garlic oil and Umami Dama paste. I added a seasoned boiled egg. My ramen arrived commendably quickly in one of their signature small based bowlsIt was an excellent bowl of ramen. Fantastic stock. Not too much bean sprout filler (I'm looking at you here, Shoryu). Soft pork with nice rim of fat. Chewy noodles. Perfect yolk on the egg. Ippudo slips into second position behind Bone Daddies in my table of favourite ramen places in LondonThe menu is currently smaller than the one in New York but it's a good idea to start small and expandWelcome, Ippudo!

ZUMzQvFPA_iqasIp0u7rqQ.text: Went for the grand opening on 10/10/14. We've been to Ippudo in New York (East Village and Midtown West) and Japan (Kyoto) and I want to start off by saying that the ramen was just as good as what we've had in both other Ippudo branches. Consistency is what we are looking for when it comes to Ippudo and the London branch totally delivered. Out of the popular New York ramen places (Ippudo, Ivan Ramen, Hide-Chan, Totto, Minca, Yuji) Ippudo is still our favorite for ramen though we love Yuji's mamezen.Anyway, I digress. When we found out Ippudo was coming to London we knew we definitely wanted to go. The space is really gorgeous, with floor to ceiling windows on all sides of the two-story restaurant. We didn't get a chance to see the upstairs but they have an open kitchen with bar seating for 7 as well two, four and large group tables on the ground floor. Luckily, Adam was able to be at Ippudo by 6pm and had been told that it would be around a 30 minute wait. It was the grand opening so there were some kinks, though I'm sure with time these will be resolved. As we waited for our table at the bar, we noticed there were two bartenders but the service was incredibly slow. It took over 30 minutes for my cocktail, the Shogalicious (£7), which consisted of aperol, fresh grapefruit, ginger and lemon all topped with prosecco to be made. We actually got seated before I received my drink. Totally a staffing/opening day issue as much of the time was spent finding ingredients/finishing prep work that I'm sure will be fixed but something to mention. However, we found that once we sat down service and wait time for food was much less than at the bar. In terms of the drink, it was quite refreshing and had a great ginger taste. Worth the wait (sort of). If you aren't interested in waiting at the bar, they are able to call/text you when your table is ready so that you can go to one of the places nearby for a drink instead. The bar is quite small and narrow, with seating for less than 10, so it's nice that they have this service for those waiting. By the time we were getting seated, the hostess was letting people know the wait was over an hour. Still better than New York's 2+ hour wait!We were seated at the bar that looked into the kitchen; however, the seats and bar were lower than the open kitchen so you can't see the whole cooking process (if that is something you're interested in). The menu has some items that we hadn't seen on the New York menu and the two that really piqued our interest was the tako wasabi (£3.80) and the homemade pickles (£5.00). The tako wasabi consisted of raw baby octopus with freshly chopped wasabi (two kinds) and was fantastic. The portion is small, so I would recommend that each person order one. The octopus was fresh and went well with the two kinds of wasabi. We quickly gobbled this up. The homemade pickles (konbu-dashi pickled tomatoes, celery, radish, cucumber, pepper and lemon paired with a sweet plum wine jelly) was the only miss of the night. So... odd and just wasn't the kind of pickles we would have thought of when one thinks Japanese. We had assumed that it would be tsukemono, such as takuan (yellow daikon pickle) and kyurizuke (cucumber pickles), but what came to the table resembled more of a crudite platter in terms of the way the vegetables were cut. The konbu-dashi pickling just wasn't to our taste, a bit too sugary and vinegary reminding us more of an Italian pickle than Japanese. Lastly, the whole cherry tomatoes had a very odd texture. Of course, we had to also have the signature Ippudo Pork Hirata Buns (£7). Just like home. They tasted exactly like what we had in New York and brought us back to nights at the East Village Ippudo. The pork belly was tender and flavorful and went well with the slightly spicy mayonnaise while the lettuce lent a bit of crunch. The soft and slightly sweet bun was a perfect vehicle. We could have eaten 5 of these but had to save room for ramen. They currently have 4 types of ramen, with two being vegetarian broths. Our favorite from New York was on the menu, the Akamaru Modern (£11), which we both ended up getting. We hadn't had ramen in such a long time that we decided to go a bit topping crazy and both added a seasoned boiled egg (£1.50), seasoned bamboo shoots/menma (£2.50) and takana leaf mustard (£2). This was heaven. The noodles were cooked so that they still had a bit of bite and the broth was rich and so satisfying. The The seasoned boiled egg still had a slightly runny yolk, which is exactly how we like it. The bamboo shoots were good and added some crunch to the ramen. The takana leaf mustard (which came on the side) added some  spiciness to the dish and Adam loved how salty it was though it was a bit too salty for me. Ippudo was exactly as we remembered from New York. What you crave on a cold winter night and where we will be weekly through the cold and wet London winter.

xUy8ZlvZmLt_x_6AtZva5A.text: I love Ippudo in New York, by far the best ramen I ever had. I am glad that I can finally enjoy the finest ramen I know in Europe.I had a pork bun and the seasonal shoyu ramen. The bun was delicious and really opened my appetite!When the Ramen arrived on my table, I couldn't wait to try them. The broth is simply delicious and is perfectly balanced. The noodles are also really delicious. I haven't find any other places that has noodles even close to Ippudo. However, I have to say that the pork was not as good as in NYC. It wasn't bad at all but I was expecting something more tender and tasty.Overall, this is a great ramen place but the price tag is probably a bit exaggerated. I paid 22£ for one person. I will probably go back but will need to find a  cheaper place for my usual ramen craving

X-l4NMOI-wWVLlhZma61hw.text: Modern interior. With music to fit the bill. Not a whole lot of space. They announce the number of guests in Japanese and everyone is then greeted in Japanese when you walk in which gives it that authentic feel.I've heard it can be busy, but there was no wait at 10 on a Wednesday night.I got the Hirata pork (3 £)In a steamed bun like the kind that goes with Peking Duck. Tasty piece of pork belly with a lightly spicy sauce. Overall pretty good if not a little over sauced.Akamaru modern (11 £)Not too spicy at all. Broth is rich but seems heavier than the consistency would make it seem.  On saltier side for me.  The noodles are the thin style ramen noodles which are different if you're expecting the regular thicker ramen.  They give you a decent amount of noodles, but it was a little on the harder side for me.Poached egg (1.50 £)You have to add your own egg.  You can get a boiled egg, but of course I got it poached.  It was actually too soft for me.  I had it in the spoon and it actually kind of fell apart sitting in the spoon.Their way of asking for more noodles is kind of interesting.  You ask for more noodles (1.50 £) when you are almost done.  They warn you that you must keep enough broth in the bowl for them to add another serving.Overall I'd say 3.5 is about on.  The pricing is a bit higher due to having to add a lot of the extras yourself.  The thinner noodles are a taste thing.  Very cool interior though.

photos.caption: Photo of Ippudo London - London, United Kingdom. Pork Hirata Bun
Photo of Ippudo London - London, United Kingdom. Akamaru Modern with poached egg

eCFW-U2TuCTTg8uu-csFgA.text: I have been to a ippudo in NYC, Manila, and Singapore and though there are some variations in the offerings, the service was good. HOWEVER, the IPPUDO at  3 Central Saint Giles Piazza;  St. Giles High Street, London has  ATROCIOUS service. After a 30 minute wait ( not unusual of ippudos), we were seated and after waiting another 15 minutes at the table, I had to get up and go find my waiter to take our orders. Our waiter 'Eric' took the order which was large sake, 4 waters, 2 ORDERS ( 6 pieces) of pork bun appetizer, 3 Karakamen ramen (2 with medium noodles and one with hard noodles) and 1 Shiromaru Hakata classic Ramen (medium noodles). and after 20 minutes he hadn't even brought our sake or water. So I got up and went over to him and then he proceeded to bring the water.  15 minutes later, someone from the kitchen showed up and brought 2 PIECES of pork bun. I asked him what happened to the other pork buns and he said that the waiter only ordered two buns. So I called our waiter Eric over and told him that I ordered two orders of pork buns which is six pieces as exactly I had explained to him however he just didn't seem to get it.  The pork buns were quite anemic with the pork filling. 95 % bun and 5 % filling. This is not the IPPUDO that I know. Also, I had ordered Karashi takana to put in the ramen but that never came until later in the meal I had to ask another waiter for it. When our ramens came, I asked him which one had the hard noodles and he said " it doesn't matter because they are all the same". WHAT?? I looked in my ramen bowl and it had mushy soft ramen noodles. I told him that I wanted hard noodles in my Karakka Ramen.   He really didn't seem to care.  I know that in other parts of the world, ippudo takes pride in the quality of the food as well as customer service, however, London's Ippudo clearly does not follow that  philosophy.  The waiter than suggested he will just bring some hard noodles which I can dump in my Ramen. WHAT?? So what am I going to do about my mushy soft noodles that are sitting in the ramen bowl mixed up with everything else that is in the bowl. The noodles don't just come out so easily without the other elements of the ramen coming out with it.     I told him that was unacceptable and I just want the Ramen noodles that I ordered.  All in all, it was a very disappointing Speary and's having been to multiple other ippudos around the world.    If you have been to other Ippudos around the world or in your own home country, do not think of this Ippudo as being related to the one that you have been to  in your own home country or at other destinations. This is clearly a very substandard ramen noodle restaurant.  I have not been to other Ramen restaurants in London but I am absolutely certain that there are other Ramen restaurant which would for outshine Ippudo. This was an extremely disappointing experience, one I will never repeat again.  Save yourselves the anticipation, excitement, or hype of an IPPUDO in London and go eat at any decent London restaurant whatever ethnicity the food is. I can't imagine the service to be any worse than this or the food quality to be such a disappointment. TRUST ME, it is just NOT THE SAME IPPUDO that you may have been to in your own home countries. Save your money. Enough said.

sP0H33Dvvzel2ATXDH8oqQ.text: I really liked ippudo - the ramen doesn't come with as many included extras as somewhere like Shoryu (which remains my favourite ramen joint) - so if you want an egg in your bowl you have to pay extra...  however the broth was really rich and flavoursome and you have a choice of which type of noodles to have and how soft or hard you want them.Definitely a place to check out if you're a ramen fan (or even if your not!)

photos.caption: Photo of Ippudo London - London, United Kingdom. The Ramen "Special"

Cm8cZ8c6PH7ZuBk17jcbMA.text: I have been here twice now... I think it is much better than my previous ippudo experience in the us. I like the fact that there are a few japanese people to overlook the kitchen so although sometimes the ratio of toppings, soups, and noodles are not really perfect, the taste combination is mostly there. The soup is very solid with pork and seafood combination and noodles are cooked and drained off very well.I saw some comments about bone daddies, etc... In my personal opinion, this is not even comparison... This is a solid japanese ramen and many other ramen places in London are japanese style ramen.., come and eat here if you want a solid bowl of ramen.I also had a bowl of rice with was - very descent. Loved the rice - was cooked very well with quality grains. Rice actually tasted better than many other japanese restaurants in London. Quite impressed.Truly a great addition to the London  japanese scene. The real test would be how this quality will be maintained without the special supervision that had been shipped in for the opening.

photos.caption: Photo of Ippudo London - London, United Kingdom. Classic hakata ramen with bowl of eel

arph7YbU-BITBvJdROqe2w.text: I can't even deal with how delicious this is/was.  Like, I left my friends and immediately texted: "I'm already having ramen flashbacks".  We literally - no seriously - asked aloud whether the dessert menu could just feature...another course of perfect tonkotsu ramen.It's great.  The music is weird (but great), the aggressive yelling is loud (but great), the waiting system where they text you instead of carrying around a ridiculous buzzer is efficient (and great!).  Service is ON POINT, and - small, but important, detail - we laughed at how "not London" their tap water is.  Big chunks of ice!  Mega-tumblers!  Quick refills!Anywho, on to the ramen.  I went for the Akamaru ramen (pork belly, miso, garlic oil, LOTSA YUM).  A quiet came over our table.  It's comforting, but complex.  And fatty, but also not heavy.  It's just...such a miraculous bowl of win.  For an additional 1.50 - I CAN NOT RECOMMEND HIGHLY ENOUGH THE SOFT-BOILED EGG.  Perfect centre, perfectly seasoned, perfect complement to the ramen.In/out, with service, for 13.50.  I know that some have gripes about the amount of pork / portion size, but I think it was generous in a great atmosphere with top quality.  Yelp note: also consumed?  The edamame which is tossed in soy with some garlic chips.  Sure.  I mean, don't get it if it'll interfere with the room in your stomach for ramen but otherwise, solid.

Vda90RHhrB201PrHbYaGmg.text: They got rid of the £10 student deal. What a shame!You can eat at the bar for fast service if you're a small party and don't want to wait for a table. The Karaka Spicy Men is spicier than the Akamaru Modern but they are generally pretty similar. Noodles are straight and thin. This is a good place to get your ramen fix.

5B8rEdnxymgZorgCTHZmvA.text: I've been to Ippudo in NYC so I was really excited to find out they had a location inLondon. I got the spicy tonkastsu ramen which was nice and spicy but not too spicy, just right! The pork and the soft boiled egg in the ramen were super duper tasty!! We also got the pork buns which were super yummy!!! If you love ramen this is an awesome spot!

D1FhF7-4g71sUVe9R6lDWg.text: I had an excellent experience here in December, 2016 -- authentic Hakata ramen (Akadama Tamago), delicious appetizers (Goma Kyuri, Kale Salad, Gyoza, Vegetarian Bun), friendly service and warm waiting area/bar!Ippudo started in Hakata, Japan.  I've been an Ippudo fan for over 15 years, even before they had many locations outside Hakata like nowadays.  Whenever I visit Tokyo now, I try to go to Ippudo at least once during my stay.  Ippudo is so good.  As for this location in London, actually I was disappointed when I had Shirodama Ramen over a year ago (March, 2015).  But I'm glad I went back.  I was very happy about their Akadama Tamago Ramen this time.  It is authentic and super delicious.  PROS:- Ramen and appetizers tasted excellent!- They have a bar/waiting area.  So, you can likely wait for a table warmly drinking a pint of beer or something.- All food on the menu are available at a bar, including ramen.  We put down our name for a table but ended up eating at a bar because we didn't want to wait!- They are VEGETARIAN FRIENDLY.  That is not UNcommon at ramen joints in London (or San Francisco where I live), but it is VERY rare in Japan.  Since my partner is vegetarian, I always appreciate restaurant's awareness and efforts to have vegetarian customers and their friends and families.  If there are no vegetarian items, I cannot go with my partner!CONS:- It took long time until ramen was served.  I was probably waiting nearly 10 mins after I finished gyoza.  Maybe that's because there was less people working in the kitchen during holidays.

DU0tcBGaVw5iColdzH2jpw.text: Like many others, we were going to the place across the street and changed our minds when we saw the line.  Yikes!We opted to try Ippudo out and were very pleasantly surprised.  We liked it so much that we actually opted to dine there again on our last night in London.    Ramen is very very tasty.   Service was spotty the first time but the 2nd time it was fabulous.  Sake is good too!

KTWiLkuF_t3equZ0qxzuUw.text: I have been to Ippudo in New York and was really eager to check out their new London restaurant, having tried a few of the ramen establishments here like Bone Daddies, Shoryu, and United Ramen. My friend and I originally decided that we would show up in Holborn and decide between Kanada-Ya and Ippudo on the spot, depending on which queue looked better, as they both don't take reservations. So when we arrived and saw 10+ people waiting outside of Kanada-Ya in the cold on the street, Ippudo was the obvious choice.Luckily, on a Monday night the wait was not that long, and I put my name down for an estimated wait of 15-20 minutes. They do the same thing as The Ship where they take down your cell phone number and then say that they will text you when your table is ready. The problem is that it didn't work so well since that when the table was ready, they came over and called out my name, and meanwhile the text message system was not notified so kept sending me texts saying that my table would be ready soon, including after we had already left the restaurant!At the bar I ordered a pint of Asahi and an order of the pork hirata buns. I was served right away and the buns came only a few minutes after I ordered them, so you don't have to worry even if you only have a short wait for a table. It was spicier than I had imagined, but the pork was tender and fatty, and it was very tasty. Unfortunately they are 2 for 7 pounds, and at that price I'm not sure if it's worth it. We paid for the food and the drinks right away, as they said that it was difficult to transfer the tab to the table since the bar and the restaurant operate separately.Once we were seated, service was extremely prompt and they came over almost immediately, expecting us to know what we wanted. There is actually quite a large selection of appetizers but only four ramen options, two with meat and two vegetarian. As we had already eaten a bit, we went straight for the ramen. I got the classic Shiromaru Hakata and my friend got the Akamaru Modern, which has garlic oil and a special red house paste. It was a solid bowl of ramen, though it did not come with an egg and there wasn't the option to add crushed garlic or sesame seeds, which is an option I find myself expecting at these specialist ramen establishments. I tried my friend's Akamaru Modern, and it did indeed have a much stronger kick to it, if that is your type of thing.I like that they don't mess around with the ramen and just serve a few classic dishes that they are good at. What I don't understand is the vibe of the restaurant, which tries to be both traditional Japanese and a cool trendy place at the same time. It is in a modern glass multi-use building in the center of London, but yet while we were being seated, the not-Japanese hostess kept shouting welcomes in Japanese and the staff would echo in Japanese when they too were mostly not Japanese. The decor is also not Japanese and the music playing was an odd blend of pop and dance tunes, with some memorable songs by Jesse McCartney and Miley Cyrus.

mmkv4qf1vy51TD-zxI3U_A.text: This is my favorite restaurant I had been to ever!  They have the best Ramen in the world in my perspective not to mention the delicious buns.  I totally reccomend to eat at this restaurant even though it may smell like cleaning products.

qtPsWuDBz4DSVL6228xoFQ.text: I was looking forward to this since visiting Ippudo in Japan, I mean REALLY REALLY looking forward to it. And what a disappointment.tldr: Food was good, service was appalling. Won't be coming back.In Japan, Ramen bars are a local grubby place where all that counts is the food - which is 99% of the time just amazing. Even chains such as Ippudo have this kind of authentic charm to them that I couldn't wait to live again in London.Well, they tried to recreate the charm, but they also added some false pompous poshness. It didn't work. At all. And it just turned it into a bad customer experience: something you wouldn't ever find in Japan.So note: you can't book a table, and you can't be seated till the whole party is there. Fair enough, they need a quick turnover. But again, this method doesn't fit with the sense of "posh" they are trying to convey in this place. So we ended up waiting at the bar, having some bar snacks and starters while waiting for the queue to grow, and grow. We finally get seated 20min (after receiving a text notification) after all our party was there.The menu is pretty simple, and offers a bit more variety that what you would find in their Japanese restaurants. Prices are acceptable, similar to what you would be paying in other ramen bars in London.And well, this is what saves them their 2 stars: the food was actually pretty decent:- The Gyoza were fantastic- The ramen was as it tasted in Japan - never been a massive fan if their noodles, but their broth is fantastic.My other half went for the spicy ramen, and added the extra spice, and went for the x15 spicyness. But beware: it is lethal. He loved it, my mouth was burning by just dipping my finger in it.We decided to skip desert and paid the bill. Wile we were just saying goodbye to our friends when one of the managers came and asked us to leave. That was pretty much the last straw.Ippudo London? Been there, done that. I'll go and satisfy my ramen-craving needs somewhere where I am not treated like kettle, thanks.

qNH0qNpGP3JY6X0tJicmQw.text: Hi guys, so my last visit I didn't even get to go inside but I returned at the end of 2014 with a friend of mine.Unfortunately the bad experience continued. Yes, when you walk in they all yell welcome in Japanese to you and something else when you leave. It is a bit weird and jarring but that's the way they do things in Japan!The problem this time was that hidden in the ramen that my friend ordered was a string. She held it up with her chopsticks and I said is that just some noodle? Nope, it's like those strings you get when you buy raw chicken, and it's in her ramen. WOW.We waved a waiter over, who saw that and promptly took the bowl away apologising all the while. In the interim another 2 waiters came along and apologised again. One of the waiters offered to replace her bowl of ramen and any extra she wanted for free. Nice gesture, though we were already full (unfortunately she was near the end of her bowl of ramen before this "discovery").The food is mediocre, the soup stock was nothing special. Coupled with the ghastly experience, I am going to stick with Kanada-Ya.

y9IziynLkO8ou14fGiQwPA.text: Ippudo finally makes it to London!Went for lunch on a weekend a couple weeks after their opening. Like the Ippudo in New York, there was a queue. I ordered the Akamaru Modern and shared my friend's gyoza. I wasn't amazed by either. The gyoza was made with chicken, and I would have preferred pork. If you're coming to a ramen restaurant famous for their tonkotsu broth, wouldn't you want to continue the pork theme? The flavor of the ramen was fine, but gave me MSG dehydration afterwards.I appreciate that Ippudo is rather new and they are keeping the menu (at least with respect to the ramen) quite simple. London has many other options for ramen and I would have preferred some specials.

photos.caption: Photo of Ippudo London - London, United Kingdom. Akamaru Modern

1LiC_8y1UzJaQ0uffzuc-g.text: After finding that several other Japanese places had no table available online, we decided to try Ippudo and just take our chances.  We had to wait about 15 min to get a table, but we were  able to sit at the bar and have a drink while we waited so no big deal. I tried plum wine for the first time.  Sweet! I liked it.To start we split the chicken karaage and the chicken gyoza (not the deep fried or boiled but normal pot sticker style).  Both were flavorful.  Then I had the basic Tonkatsu Ramen.  It was really nice.  Great broth, tender pork and perfect chewy noodles.  My coworker had the vegetarian ramen, with egg added.  He said was really good.  He also had the tempura chicken to go on top of the ramen (since all the meat ramen issues are pork based and he is Muslim).  He said it was really good.Overall, glad we went.  Service was fine.  Nothing amazing, but the guy was friendly and we got what we needed when we needed it.  I would totally go back again.

lkd9aFKC4D67m3MSnMY7NQ.text: I was reminded today of why I love Ippudo. This is the fourth Ippudo location I have dined at, and the ramen did not disappoint. All of the dishes Ipuudo is known for were on the menu.  Plus a few UK-inspired ones. Up until today, the most memorable Ippudo ramen special I ate was the black sesame oil miso ramen in NYC in 2012.  And today it was knocked off of it's pedestal by London's current special, Red Tan-Tan Men. In short, Red Tan-Tan Men is the most unique and best ramen I've ever eaten. EVER. ****IF YOU CAN HANDLE SPICY RAMEN, THEN ORDER IT WHILE YOU STILL CAN**** The special just became available yesterday and is available through the end of June 2016. The wait staff believe it to be available only in London because each chef at each location comes up with their own creation.  Read on if you want the details... THE BOWL: white in colorTHE NOODLES: As usual, the straight noodles were perfect. (You have the option of getting it hard, medium, or soft.  I chose medium.)THE TOPPINGS: (1) cilantro, or coriander leaves as they are called in the UK, was... a first for me to eat w ramen; (2) chili oil has a nice mild-medium kick; (3) a poached egg comes on the side, which is meant to be added to the broth; the whites had the texture of silken tofu, and the yolk was a creamy soft boil; (4) 3 fried wontons are small, and have chicken and vegetable filling, and usually come in the broth, but I asked them to put it on the side (because I hate soggy fried anything); (5) spicy nikumiso paste, which is SUPER SUPER SUPER  spicy (!!!); luckily the waiter warned me, so I asked for it on the side (so that I could control the spiciness of my broth) my best guess is that it is made up of ground pork, miso, and very spicy red chili oil.  (6) sweet vinegar (comes on the side in a bottle) which is meant to be added to the brothTHE BROTH: First of all, this is a CHICKEN BROTH, not a pork broth. So the flavor is obviously different, but it has a similar level of "depth" as the pork broth minus the greasy feeling on your lips. Also, there are instructions on how to "layer on" the toppings to achieve different broth complexities.  Here is how I ate it:(1) first try the original base soup... It's rich in flavor and has a mild-medium spicy kick from the chili oil. (2) the instructions tell you to add the nikumiso paste next but since it was so spicy, I decided to do it last and, instead, added in the egg next. And OMG it was amazing. It gave the broth a nice creamy and silky texture; (3) then next came the sweet vinegar. I was nervous about this one since I didn't know what to expect. So I only added a little at a time as I ate. But wow did it made it even more amazing. It was just the right acidity and sweetness. Sweet, sour, and salty all in one bite. I was I heaven; (4) then finally came the nikumiso paste.  I've made the mistake of underestimating spicy paste before (rendering it inedible), and I never wanted to ruin another ramen bowl ever again, so I'm really glad I asked for it on the side, because it was way to spicy for me to add it directly to the broth; so I asked for a small empty bowl, which I used to "dilute" the spiciness by adding a little bit of broth.  I semi-drained the ground pork in small batches throughout the rest of my meal. This required extra work but was worth it to me because it was even more delicious.  There is a recommendation on the instruction card to add rice to your broth at the end. But I didn't try it, since the noodles were so good on their own.  Does it need additional toppings? Well, the wontons provide a nice crispy texture to contrast the rich creamy broth. I wish I had more than just 3 wontons. But in terms of adding the other toppings (seaweed, onions, chaushu, etc), no, I felt it was right just the way it is.e

_VIWlOLnY8jRYMaRzw1mCw.text: A great ramen contender in London. Their selection of ramen is wide enough to satisfy everyone's tastes. The sides are good and drinks menu is good too. You won't be let down!Before I started to explore other ramen places in London, IPPUDO was my favourite for a long time. I have been here numerous times and never ever been let down. But saying that, the ramen isn't the best in London now I have explored.The restaurant interior is modern, the atmosphere is good, and the service is great too. I don't have a bad word about IPPUDO other than there are better tasting ramen out there.

photos.caption: Photo of Ippudo London - London, United Kingdom

iMJcx6XGgB1DGz-OywrSbw.text: Ippudo was recommended to me by a friend and the ramen did not disappoint!My husband and I started with the pork buns which were small but delicious. For our main, of course we decided to take one of the many ramens offered. I don't understand how anyone can come here and not eat the ramen! It was a difficult decision and in the end I decided on the spicy tonkotsu and my husband ordered the London Exclusive. Both were excellent.The service is holding me back from giving a fifth star. We had to wait for our table, so we ordered two drafts at the bar. My drink was almost finished when we were seated so I went ahead and ordered my next drink which never arrived. Once I finished both courses (starter and main) he came over with my drink but by then it was too late! So definitely order a big drink from the start, because it's the only one you'll get during your meal!

photos.caption: Photo of Ippudo London - London, United Kingdom. I wish I had ordered the larger size since my waiter never brought me my second glass...
Photo of Ippudo London - London, United Kingdom. Hirata pork bun
Photo of Ippudo London - London, United Kingdom. Exterior

58QlnxmHqhfG_puShmemZg.text: Not the best ramen, but it's solidly good, especially for a casual lunch or quick dinner.I always get hirata pork bun, followed by Akamaru Modern and then green tea. The ramen is very garlicky, but clean tasting and you can always add a boiled egg for more protein.I actually prefer Kanada-ya, across the street, but their queue is very long most days. Ippudo is reliable and consistent, whether you're in Sydney, London, or New York.

photos.caption: Photo of Ippudo London - London, United Kingdom

RuSJaSMP8KwmkEwTxnGnJg.text: I love Ippudo! I went to the one in Manhattan every now and then, and I missed the richness of their broth. Very few ramen shops have super rich broths like Ippudo.I got the spicy ramen, and boy the broth was incredibly thick. But it was super rich and flavorful, just like I wanted. It was a bit spicy, but not enough to make it undrinkable. I thought the meat was okay (I've had better) but they really do a good job with the broth here.Service here is whatever, but I think that's just how most of Europe is.Prices seem on par with what they are in the U.S.  The seating is a bit more open here too compared to the one in Manhattan.
