WIVhQDB5w2ByjLUbqPcUSw.text: I'm still on a quest to find good ramen in London.  I'm starting to feel it doesn't exist here.Gyoza - pass. will not order again, but portions were decent.  Small hot sake - standard 250ml (I had half b/c I'm a lite weight these days)Hakata Classic - good, but I've had better.Slap on the Ippudo name and charge £££All in all, the meal cost me US$55. I left full, but US$55 for ramen/gyoza dinner for one person is a bit much (expense account or not).  The food was OK, but  wasn't spectacular.Easy to find location and the queue wasn't so bad.  I sat at the communal table which didn't bother me because I actually had elbow space this time.

photos.caption: Photo of Ippudo London - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Ippudo London - London, United Kingdom. Gyoza: 5

qaFpZ996VgigezUh4XonDQ.text: Pretty decent ramen, but not as good as the New York location. The tonkotsu ramen was a bit uneventful, hot but lacking in flavour. The nigori sake was nice, bit dull, and sort of... chunkier than I expected? Service was great, though. Interior decoration felt sort of like "tacky Japanese," like sort of what a western business person might imagine connoted "Japaneseness" to other western clientele?

photos.caption: Photo of Ippudo London - London, United Kingdom. Nigori sake served with ice in the interior of the carafe!

zh9OrG4rotYX31hUEwgXXw.text: Nom nom nom!We arrived just before 7pm and had to wait about 30minutes (but at least we could wait with a drink by the bar, rather than out in the cold.) The Akamaru ramen was really gorgeous. The noodles were perfect, the broth had a deep, porky, garlicky (and delicious) flavour. The portions were good for me, but I know my Japanese colleagues will say it's a bit small...at least you can order kaedama if you need extra noodles. The eggs weren't the best in London, but they were good. The pork hirata buns were really, really tasty too. The only thing I didn't love was all the shouting. I think it is awesome that they have taught all the staff two phrases in Japanese, "irrashaimase", and "arigatou gozaimasu"...but some folks really managed to massacre those few words. As we were leaving there were sooo many cheers of "aRIgatoh - go-ZI-masu" it got a little bit jarring (and was a bit overkill - surely they don't ALL need to say it!?) They have a few staff that were able to speak Japanese well...maybe it'd be better if they allowed them to be the only greeters!?

jwbK7aIwwmI_H_ceDw7Pbg.text: Terrific ramen just like you'd gone in Japan.  I'd get hard noodles and the misco broth.

_n5Ce9_scVlF7H1-N8deFQ.text: Having first tried it in Kuala Lumpur, we were truly excited to when Ippudo finally opened its first store in London. We actually visited back in December 2015 so the ramen and food might be slight different. We had two of their hirata buns: their classic pork bun with signature soft braised pork belly and chicken katsu bun. A little slice of iceberg lettuce adds a nice crunch to the dish, otherwise you'd literally feel like you're eating air since the bun is so soft and fluffy! A thin layer of mayo and a special chilli sauce combines everything together. A must try if you go to Ippudo!Next we tucked into the lovely ramen. Each came topped with 2 slices of their famous tender pork belly, spring onions, kikurage mushrooms and a dash of black garlic oil. Don't be put off by the garlic oil though, think of it like when you add a dash of sesame oil to your stir-fry - its an added level of fragrance to the dish!First up is the Akamaru Modern (£11.00) - Ippudo call this their "bolder  translation" of their classic pork broth, as its got their secret special blended miso paste (fermented soya beans).If you like miso, then this is definitely one for you.Second, we had the Karaka-Men (£11.00) - Ippudo's original tonkotsu broth with a blob of their spicy miso paste. Definitely not for the faint hearted. The depth of the chilli really hits the back of your throat, yet it's not too overpowering as you can still taste the intensity of the pork broth.A meal wouldn't be finished unless we had dessert too! We opted for the Houji-Cha Pudding (£5.00). This was a smooth milky-like pudding, similar to the pana cotta. The pudding is flavoured with roasted tea and topped with a layer of sweet kuromitsu sauce (black honey). The whipped cream on top is flavoured with honey. Nothing we've ever eaten before, so slightly weird, but oddly satisfying! Personally we think Ippudo ramen reminded us the ramen we've tried in Tokyo and Kyoto...

photos.caption: Photo of Ippudo London - London, United Kingdom. Ippudo Houjicha-pudding
Photo of Ippudo London - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Ippudo London - London, United Kingdom. Ippudo Karaka-men ramen

h2S8TIKW5yaqNlQM04gwYg.text: Ippudo is my favourite ramen house in NYC and was so excited to see it opening in London!  Walked into Ippudo on day eight of their opening on a Friday night at 8:15 PM to find it was a two hour wait.  We put our name in and luckily found a place at the bar to cozy up. They have a great system where they text you when your table is ready so you can go somewhere else to grab a drink if the bar is full.  The wait actually turned out to be one hour and we were ready to eat.Food: For appetisers we ordered the amazing pork hirata buns which are just as amazing in London and the hirata chicken wings which were good, but very peppery.  We chose the Hakata Shiromaru Classic (added an extra egg) and the Akamaru Modern ramens.  Both were deeeelicious!Drinks: We ordered one glass of the Ichinokura Tokubetsu Junmai sake.  (We ordered two beers and one glass of wine at the bar on a separate tab while waiting.)Price: 53.44 GBP for two people.Ambiance: The restaurant is pretty big (two floors) and has a ton of energy like the one in NYC does.  We sat downstairs at one of the communal tables.Service: The service was very efficient.  I mean spot on.  But it didn't feel like you were rushed in any way. Everyone was super friendly from the hosts, the server, the food runners, etc.  I was very impressed because you don't usually get good friendly service in London.Would I go back?  Definitely!  It's a taste of home for me.  I am so happy that finally both Ippudo and Kanada-ya are here in London to show how ramen is really supposed to be served.

photos.caption: Photo of Ippudo London - London, United Kingdom. Akamaru Modern Ramen
Photo of Ippudo London - London, United Kingdom. Hakata Shiromaru Ramen with extra side of egg

yb0ZgW_q4WUqcu__tWmYQQ.text: I had a great experience at Ippudo. The wait on Wednesday night ~7pm was about 20 minutes which we gladly spent at the bar. I don't drink alcohol, but the bartender was kind enough to whip me up his own virgin mocktail creation - lychee, strawberry, calpis and fizz...it was the cutest drink (and very yummy). We ordered the karaage (fried chicken) and the pancake as starters - yum! We were pleased with both. The chicken portion isn't the biggest and comes with only about 4-5 pieces, but it's very tender. The pancake was gorgeous and still piping hot on the pan.I got the regular white bowled tonkotsu ramen (I don't remember the full name of it...but it's the first option on the menu) and was very pleased even if it's simple and straightforward. Do ask for sesame, crushed garlic, and chili oil to add into your ramen. The ramen is the thinner kind, and you can tell it's real fresh. When we entered, everyone shouts Japanese greetings at you....and when you leave, everyone shouts Japanese goodbyes and well wishes. It's kind of endearing.

photos.caption: Photo of Ippudo London - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Ippudo London - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Ippudo London - London, United Kingdom

M04PeHD616jRMXzrLs3sMg.text: Fabulous dinner stop on a rainy Monday evening. My younger sister has only moved to London a few weeks ago and still somehow managed to scope out this place before me. Her description of it sounded so tasty that I insisted she go again and take me!Anywhere with a roof would have been welcome shelter after sploshing our way over from the bus stop, but this place was particularly nice to enter, with the glow from the gleaming wooden interior visible through the glass frontage. We arrived at a quite early 6.45pm so were happy to wait when she said it'd take about 20mins for a table. They have one of those systems that texts you when your table is ready but given the rain we weren't going anywhere fast. We pulled up 2 high chairs at the bar instead and enjoyed the decor around us with ramen bowls on display overhead and dried noodle squares set into the counter. We both like plum wine in Japanese places so ordered Plumpop cocktails - prosecco, plum wine and orange bitters with a strawberry.Before the barman had finished making them though the front-of-house came over and asked if we'd mind counter seating; we didn't, so could be seated then. We walked round to a row of seats lining the kitchen, so they all face into the chefs' food prep area, and are suitable for solo diners or two's. Our cocktails followed us and were delicious. Food-wise we were too intrigued by other parts of the menu to order the traditional ramen which seems to be the specialty here. Instead we went for a chicken hirata bun each, which was so tasty that next time I might just gobble 5 buns myself for a meal. For main, we shared a Japanese savoury pancake stuffed with pork belly and cabbage and made with their pork broth, and a sizzling pot of noodles with minced chicken and tofu. Both were incredibly hot (in temperature) but the flavours were delicious (once the feeling in my tongue returned).Our server was very friendly, and they make an effort to speak a few words of Japanese to say thank you and bye which I thought was a nice touch. It's probably on the pricey side for what the food is but it's a swish little setting right in the middle of central London so I think much as expected. Best for smaller groups or date night I think; the hardest part was resisting nabbing one of the big red ramen bowls on the way out - my sis definitely had her eye on one to use at home!

TQWHCcnCAMkSb7UBCYd1mw.text: Excellent broth, chashu pork is lacking in quality (at least when I ate there) but isn't a deal breaker. Toppings are great, especially the exquisite egg which comes whole and drips into the broth when you split it. The noodles were a bit softer than expected for the "hard" level I asked for.The atmosphere is nice, although the welcome in Japanese is a bit over the top...

uY7y9Dr6JvpW1Ch_tkix2w.text: Excellent soft opening. I've had Ippudo in Japan, NY, and London.  And I can honestly say, this is way better than the experience in NY.  There is a strong energetic, welcoming feeling as you enter the glossy restaurant.  The chefs and staff are yelling "WELCOME" in Japanese so often, you gotta wonder when they have time to cook.  All of the servers/staff were well trained and did their jobs with alacrity and care for my experience.  I pretty much forgot I was in London.I ordered two different ramens: Hakata (white, comes in white bowl) and the Akamaru (red, comes in red bowl and comes with red paste and seasoned oil).  The base of the two ramens taste similar, but the red was a bit preferred this time (probably due to the red paste and additional seasoning oil).  The pork was outstanding--thick and delicious and really not as fatty as I've experienced in other places.  If I were to get an "extra' for my ramen, a soft boiled egg (which is an art unto itself) is always a good and worthwhile add-on.Asahi Dry draft (a pilsner)--excellent and cold as should be expected.  I also ordered a Kale Salad to see what they were doing with it.  Usually Japanese restaurants have very fresh, well prepared greens and great dressings.  I'd say the Kale salad with fruit, nuts, and sesame dressing did not disappoint.  I won't be thinking of it in my sleep or craving it, but if you're looking for a superfood addition, this will do more than fine.You may be going with your work buddies or on a cool date, but the ramen is good enough that it may take you to a solitary space for a few bites.  Good ramen demands introspection, thought, appreciation as you bring your face close into the bowl to inhale and slurp politely.  Sometimes the simplest things are the hardest to do (well).I haven't tried ramen anywhere else in London, but I can say this blows away the New York Ippudo by good measure.  This restaurant is beautiful and spacious and the ramen actually tastes close to Japan (and is a lot less expensive than flying out there).  Great experience at Ippudo--congratulations on building a new dining experience in the UK.

photos.caption: Photo of Ippudo London - London, United Kingdom. Some of the best pork I've had in ramen.  Note the thickness.
Photo of Ippudo London - London, United Kingdom. Hakata shiro (white) ramen comes in a white bowl.  The soft done egg is always a good extra to get in any ramen.
Photo of Ippudo London - London, United Kingdom. Kale Salad.  Sesame dressing, fruit and nuts.

qHAQnu2MnIMqx6AR_vCdwQ.text: This is my favorite ramen. I prefer this over the NYC branch, the same dishes taste the same, but there are better veggie options in London (as usual) and better service in London (definitely not as usual!).  It's more spacious, relaxing and comfortable than the NYC one. London has shorter lines too.

photos.caption: Photo of Ippudo London - London, United Kingdom

8ERDy0AHtEoNSekeRRTUEg.text: I can't believe I haven't reviewed Ippudo yet, but maybe it's a subconscious thing because I don't really want to share it? It's the best ramen in London and I have a hard time finding ramen I can have as ramen is usually made with pork broth, but Ippudo makes a fantastic vegetarian broth that is so damn good it is better than some chicken ramen broths I have had in the past. This has become one of my favourite places in the city and there is nothing better than a hot bowl of steaming perfectly chewy yet soft noodles on a chilly evening. I always add the egg, which comes cold but if I let it sit in the broth for a little while, I get a perfectly melty center that is yummy. The tofu is not my favourite but the bean sprouts are delicious and I find that I can never make it to adding extra noodles (it's an option for people who have leftover broth they want to use) because I always finish what I have. There is also a really lovely chicken hirata bun appetiser here that is fluffy bun goodness with teriyaki flavour. The gyoza is also some of the best I've had and is steaming hot and perfect. I once had the fish and chips appetiser here and although it was well-made, I would say it is actually way too filling and I was actually really sad when my ramen came and I was too full to have much of it. They don't do takeaway so don't make that mistake. The iced green tea was also too strong for me, and the fried chicken appetiser was nice but not my favourite. The ramen is basically the star at this restaurant and it's a well-deserved title. The decor here is glam with its gorgeous chandeliers and yet somehow cosy and comfortable at the same time. I would warn you that the waiting time can be long if you come on a Saturday night, so come early if that's your day.

photos.caption: Photo of Ippudo London - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Ippudo London - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Ippudo London - London, United Kingdom. Fish appetiser

8mcthOrr3B2C5X-rEEgzCA.text: Did not disappoint. Loved the chicken and pork buns! The original ramen is so comforting and the noodles are cooked perfectly.

y5HyulvTKeneCnyUOT6U1w.text: Great ramen spot in London. Modern and fun atmosphere, solid service, and lots of good veggie options. Their vegetarian ramen is fantastic.

Vgo2gJ5EGemJomLGaprPkA.text: While the shape of the restaurant is odd as hell, you can't go wrong with good ol' classic Ippudo. It's the same delicious thin noodles we all know so well, on par with the quality of the Ippudo in the Bay Area, not as good as the one in New York, but an ideal option for those hunting for a ramen fix in a fairly busy area saturated with chains and cafe food.Go "hard" on the noodles, as they'll soften over time. Tonkatsu is a good starting point, then go from there. If you're feeling extra hungry, you can always add more noodles to the soup. Bonus: this area seems to be pretty good about getting folks in and out, so typically no wait! Nioce!

HQr-t91Kiix8AqW2hP42ug.text: This Ippudo lives up to the hype. Beautiful decors, good service, excellent dishes! Striking decor. Comfortable noise level. Note the doors toward the street are all sealed. The real entrance is on the plaza side. Tonkatsu ramen is most excellent especially the soup. Next time I would skip the edamame (it's good but nothing special).

photos.caption: Photo of Ippudo London - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Ippudo London - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Ippudo London - London, United Kingdom

qQ_PEi0xM9ZjfkiciH2vYQ.text: I've always really liked the Ippudo ramen chain around the world since the noodles are really thin and you can choose how hard it is. I recommend getting "hard" noodles. The cucumber appetizer is nice and refreshing to pair with your ramen. Sometimes the soup gets too salty for me so it's nice to have something lighter to go with it. If it's your first time there, i recommend getting the classic pork broth (it's usually on the first page). It's what they're most known for.

Gd4NacRKVHcjZ0k7of6SDA.text: This was my second visit to this location and it was better than the first. It was a busy Friday but we managed to get seats at the bar rather than waiting for a table.Staff service was quick and accomodating. We had seen one of their specials offered and so my companion decided to try it. I went with one of their classics. Each of us was impressed with our selection.My ramen had a thick pork broth with a slightly spicy garlic sesame oil. The broth held its flavour and the egg was cooked just right, medium boiled. Noodles were served as requested, hard. It was an excellent portion size. My partner enjoyed his bowl, having the poached egg served on the side along with hot sauce. His broth was slightly milder and boasted pulled pork. They have a decent drink menu if you fancy sake, cocktails and mocktails. Although it's an international chain it's easy to see why they have been successful.

photos.caption: Photo of Ippudo London - London, United Kingdom. Monthly special: Hakata Nikuton
Photo of Ippudo London - London, United Kingdom. Akamaru tamago

DGGa7WTZsg-24MtCXMuDfw.text: No idea what happened here, but the broth was super watery and plain. The noodles were too hard and the meats were bland. It's hard to make great ramen, but it's also hard to make terrible ramen -- it looks like Ippudo London has managed to do just that. Interestingly enough, I've gone to the Paris branch of Ippudo and it was much, much better, so I'm not sure what's going on here in London...

TzisMg-9LvbaiGNbA0IN2A.text: We have been wanting to check out Ippudo for a while. So happy that it is right next to our hotel! We arrived a little before 6 on a Thursday evening. No wait. The ramen here is good and you can pick the chewiness of the noodles which we have never experienced before. There can be a bit more toppings but overall good. Not the best ramen I've had but it was worth the try!

rgDzuOxUVz1tOPRt9m2ORQ.text: The thing I liked about this place was their broad menu. It had any kind of ramen you can think of and on top of that you can create the heat and style of noodles you prefer. This is something I've never had the luxury of doing before, so I was quite excited. Not into ramen? That's okay, because they have a lot of other things on their menu you can choose from.A part from the tasty/wide ranges of food choices and their neat interior decorations, I would say I was very disappointed with how our server was treating us. She was extremely rude from the moment we walked in the door to the moment we left. She was just as short as possible and very adamant that we hurry up and order, eat our food and get out.

photos.caption: Photo of Ippudo London - London, United Kingdom. 8 and 4 Ramen
Photo of Ippudo London - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Ippudo London - London, United Kingdom

EZjj5Uf0_O2N4IgoAwP50A.text: Still love the noodles even in this London version of the restaurant. There's a different vibe in this location but mostly because it's so large compared to the New York restaurant. I thought that the staff was friendly, the food was served quickly, and the noodles were of good quality. It's a great alternative to busier ramen shops in the area, and it's comforting to know that this is so nearby. There are a few different broth offerings and different than the NY menu--the London menu seemed more extensive, with a number of hot dishes, appetizers, and a decent sake/wine/beer selection.

LU0z5Faup1HSCrNEKSA3GA.text: Set behind Tottenham Court road station Ippudo is a Japanese Ramen and beef restaurant that is great for a quick stopover if you are in the area. First there is no way to book this restaurant. This was OK for us as we were just popping in following a visit to an exhibition. We waited at the bar with its snazzy noodle counter which would look amazing at night. We  helped ourselves to some Sparkling Hana-Fuga cocktail Sake. For the price per bottle we got two champagne glasses worth. I suspect that this is the alcopop of Japanese sake with its sweet fruity taste. We both did enjoy it as it went straight to our heads even with a 5% alcohol content. It took around 20 minutes for a table to become free and we were seated in the rather cavernous interior. This place has top to toe windows but it lacks some of the character that you would expect from a Japanese restaurant. However as there were quite a few Japanese people dining here I suppose this is acceptable place to eat. We decided to go for the Ramen. I had the shiromaru classic with an egg which is called something else and cost more. The waiter asked how I wanted the noodles. Soft or hard. Being a bit of a weakling I took the soft option. I also ordered a cha su pork bun. This was very satisfying. The bun was soft and somewhat doughy, the pork was glazed in a sweet syrup and went well with the mayonnaise and lazy salad leaf that had been tucked in. When the Ramen arrived the egg was on top uncut. This was a bit of a surprise.. had the cooks become lazy. It did spoil the picture I took but hey ho it was still quite tasty even though probably pre-cooked. The soup had a strong pork flavour and went well with the chashu, sesame kikurage mushrooms, bean sprouts, bamboo shoots and spring onions. I gobbled it down but I think I have had better a few weeks earlier. To down all the food we ordered some sake. I love the chilled variety which is cloudy and easier to drink than the paint stripper sake which is considered finer. We had no room for dessert. One thing I found lacking here was the lack of display. Servings were carried out on rather bland plates and glasses. Much like the place it lacks real Japanese character. Room for improvement I think.

1UBaNMGomIurUek7m1HjNg.text: Better pork than Kanadaya, but kanadaya has better soup, noodle or egg in my opinion. Ippudo's soup is also rich and flavoursome, but it starts to leave the salty feel in the mouth afterward which is not very pleasant. You can also customise the hardness of your noodle to however you like, and the noodle is thinner than that in kanadaya. However even when I ordered 'hard', I find it too soft to my liking - perhaps I should have went for 'extra hard' due to the thinness of their noodle. Overall still a very pleasant experience at Ippudo, but I personally prefer kanadaya.

photos.caption: Photo of Ippudo London - London, United Kingdom. Ippudo ramen

hnB6zL6921VsT4Q4g3CSrw.text: I will note that I may be used to a more fusion/Americanized version of ramen and Japanese food, but I was incredibly disappointed by the quality of the food as well as the preparation. The chicken karaage was mostly squishy yellow fat, and the pieces so undercooked that the breading was barely crisp on the outside, and it was legitimately raw beneath the surface. I had to literally scrape away blobs of raw batter off the minuscule pieces of chicken, which lacked marinade and seasoning. Inedible in my opinion. The ramen also left much to be desired. What was advertised as having many vegetables, came with 1 baby corn sliced in half and some bamboo shoots and anemic bean sprouts. The broth was thick and tasty, but the noodles were mushy, limp, and lifeless. All in all, a disappointing meal, except for the rose green tea. So they've perfected the art of tea, but the two major staples like ramen and karaage have left me disappointed, especially at the established price points.Would highly recommend going to an indie ramen shop in Soho than this chain restaurant.

photos.caption: Photo of Ippudo London - London, United Kingdom. Tonoktsu ramen
Photo of Ippudo London - London, United Kingdom. Near raw chicken karaage
Photo of Ippudo London - London, United Kingdom. Menu

CIjyd-jNQUabhFKFPBu4YQ.text: I liked the ramen here, but it wasn't that memorable. My two friends and I shared pork buns (soft, nice flavor) as apps, and I had the shiromaru classic (a bit bland?). Fine food, but I'm not itching to return here. I much prefer the nearby Kanada-Ya, even with the much longer wait.Basically, if you're not that picky about ramen and are looking for a quick bite in a spacious (quite beautiful, actually) restaurant, then Ippudo is right up your alley. But if you're a ramen fanatic, then this might not be the place for you.

JFz415ydgmV-tHqzp31S9w.text: Many Londoners tend to abandon Ippudo in favor of Kanada-ya located across the street but I remain loyal to the former.  Kanada-ya fans relentlessly queue up for hours no matter if it's wet or cold outside just to get their hands on a bowl of their ramen - a bit extreme for me, but so long as that means my nonexistent wait at Ippudo isn't affected then I don't mind at all.  I'm accustomed to massive lines and hour plus waits at the Ippudo NY locations so it's always a relief when I come here and am seated immediately.Since Ippudo is a chain, their ramen is pretty standard across all the branches I've visited so I always know what to expect.  I order the karakka-men about 80% of the time because I appreciate its spicy kick, but all the other choices are equally slurpalicious.  I wouldn't say it's the best ramen I've ever had, but the broth is flavorful and hits the spot on a chilly day. Oh, and don't forget to add the nitamago, it will elevate your ramen experience for sure.

mwxZ7R0TOhOYz5EzQ1l5Pw.text: So far the best ramen Ive had in London.I prefer it to Kanada Ya and Bone daddies because I think its the best of both world. The pork broth is juicy, ramen are thin and perfectly thin plus you can get a poached egg instead of the classic soft boiled egg. Also the chashu pork is a bit thicker which gives an extra touch to the whole combo.But I would come back to any of them any time!!!

photos.caption: Photo of Ippudo London - London, United Kingdom. The main event: akamaru modern with poached egg and extra chashu pork!!!

uLM_-7PeCs5lfZ3sjJB1Zw.text: Ramen is great here and always comes with a soft boiled egg which is great. Bit annoying. When you have to pay extra for an egg *cough cough* bone daddies * cough cough * Saying that...Ippudo isn't inexpensive. A ramen and pork bun (singular) will set you back ~£18. Nice place for a casual dinner or a date. Turned up a little late, they didn't let my friend sit down till I arrived?? Meh Ramen: 8 spicy boiled eggs / 11Pork Hirata Buns: 17 sesame seeds/ 21Atmosphere 6 DJ Khaleds / 10. ....but then at 8pm the restaurant started playing some dope tracks. Another one after another one. Atmosphere bumped up to 8/10. Overall a good experience, tasty food. Would recommend if you're looking for a ramen joint and don't mind paying the extra buck. Would I go here again? Yes. Would I order a f*ck load more pork buns. Yes. Yes I would.

5zDUcJFiW_X0xrHa5eU9aA.text: It's all about the broth when it comes to Ramen and this place did not disappoint. Was it the best Ramen I've ever had? No, but it was very good and the pork belly was cooked perfectly. The broth needed no extra seasoning and the soft egg was just right.

Aps2bhRacy-ikzCEr8jmwQ.text: I had been to the Ippudo in Paris, and the London branch was no different (as expected). Will it satisfy your ramen craving while you're abroad? Yes. Will you want to come back all the time? For an expensive, okay bowl of ramen, probably not. My friend and I both had the lunch special, which included ramen, a side dish and iced green tea. The Karaka-men broth was the perfect amount of spice, but aside from that, pretty average. Location is convenient and the interior is clean and modern. Brace yourself for your warm welcome inside, it'll make part of you want to hide back behind the curtain!

MRJfBzi0x65_h3FQ02q8Zg.text: This has to be my favorite ramen place in London.   The staff are all super friendly and welcoming and the atmosphere is very pleasant.   Look no further for the best ramen in town.   I can't recommend Ippudo enough.  I look forward to my next trip to London so I can come back.
